location: The same. A hall in Timon's house.

lines.text: Enter two Servants of Varro, and the Servant of  LUCIUS, meeting TITUS, HORTENSIUS, and other Servants of TIMON's creditors, waiting his coming out

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: Well met; good morrow, Titus and Hortensius.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: The like to you kind Varro.

lines.speaker: hortensius
lines.text: Lucius! What, do we meet together? Lucilius' Servant Ay, and I think One business does command us all; for mine Is money.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: So is theirs and ours. Lucilius' Servant And Sir Philotus too!
Enter PHILOTUS

lines.speaker: philotus
lines.text: Good day at once. Lucilius' Servant                   Welcome, good brother. What do you think the hour? Labouring for nine. Lucilius' Servant So much? Is not my lord seen yet? Lucilius' Servant Not yet. I wonder on't; he was wont to shine at seven. Lucilius' Servant Ay, but the days are wax'd shorter with him: You must consider that a prodigal course Is like the sun's; but not, like his, recoverable. I fear 'tis deepest winter in Lord Timon's purse; That is one may reach deep enough, and yet Find little. I am of your fear for that.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: I'll show you how to observe a strange event. Your lord sends now for money.

lines.speaker: hortensius
lines.text: Most true, he does.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: And he wears jewels now of Timon's gift, For which I wait for money.

lines.speaker: hortensius
lines.text: It is against my heart. Lucilius' Servant Mark, how strange it shows, Timon in this should pay more than he owes: And e'en as if your lord should wear rich jewels, And send for money for 'em. I'm weary of this charge, the gods can witness: I know my lord hath spent of Timon's wealth, And now ingratitude makes it worse than stealth. Varro's

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: Yes, mine's three thousand crowns: what's yours? Lucilius' Servant Five thousand mine. Varro's 'Tis much deep: and it should seem by the sun, Your master's confidence was above mine; Else, surely, his had equall'd. Enter FLAMINIUS.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: One of Lord Timon's men. Lucilius' Servant Flaminius! Sir, a word: pray, is my lord ready to come forth?

lines.speaker: flaminius
lines.text: No, indeed, he is not.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: We attend his lordship; pray, signify so much.

lines.speaker: flaminius
lines.text: I need not tell him that; he knows you are too diligent. Lucilius' Servant Ha! is not that his steward muffled so? He goes away in a cloud: call him, call him.
Exit
Enter FLAVIUS in a cloak, muffled

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: Do you hear, sir? Varro's

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: By your leave, sir,--

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: What do ye ask of me, my friend?

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: We wait for certain money here, sir.

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: Ay, If money were as certain as your waiting, 'Twere sure enough. Why then preferr'd you not your sums and bills, When your false masters eat of my lord's meat? Then they could smile and fawn upon his debts And take down the interest into their gluttonous maws. You do yourselves but wrong to stir me up; Let me pass quietly: Believe 't, my lord and I have made an end; I have no more to reckon, he to spend. Lucilius' Servant Ay, but this answer will not serve. If 'twill not serve,'tis not so base as you; For you serve knaves. Varro's
Exit

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: How! what does his cashiered worship mutter? Varro's

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: No matter what; he's poor, and that's revenge enough. Who can speak broader than he that has no house to put his head in? such may rail against great buildings.
Enter SERVILIUS

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: O, here's Servilius; now we shall know some answer.

lines.speaker: servilius
lines.text: If I might beseech you, gentlemen, to repair some other hour, I should derive much from't; for, take't of my soul, my lord leans wondrously to discontent: his comfortable temper has forsook him; he's much out of health, and keeps his chamber. Lucilius' Servant: Many do keep their chambers are not sick: And, if it be so far beyond his health, Methinks he should the sooner pay his debts, And make a clear way to the gods. Good gods!

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: We cannot take this for answer, sir.

lines.speaker: flaminius
lines.text: [Within]  Servilius, help! My lord! my lord!
Enter TIMON, in a rage, FLAMINIUS following

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What, are my doors opposed against my passage? Have I been ever free, and must my house Be my retentive enemy, my gaol? The place which I have feasted, does it now, Like all mankind, show me an iron heart? Lucilius' Servant Put in now, Titus.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: My lord, here is my bill. Lucilius' Servant Here's mine.

lines.speaker: hortensius
lines.text: And mine, my lord. Both Varro's Servants And ours, my lord.

lines.speaker: philotus
lines.text: All our bills.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Knock me down with 'em: cleave me to the girdle. Lucilius' Servant Alas, my lord,- Cut my heart in sums.

lines.speaker: titus
lines.text: Mine, fifty talents.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Tell out my blood. Lucilius' Servant Five thousand crowns, my lord. Five thousand drops pays that. What yours?--and yours? Varro's

lines.speaker: first servant
lines.text: My lord,-- Varro's

lines.speaker: second servant
lines.text: My lord,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Tear me, take me, and the gods fall upon you!
Exit

lines.speaker: hortensius
lines.text: 'Faith, I perceive our masters may throw their caps at their money: these debts may well be called desperate ones, for a madman owes 'em.
Exeunt
Re-enter TIMON and FLAVIUS

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: They have e'en put my breath from me, the slaves. Creditors? devils!

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: My dear lord,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: What if it should be so?

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: My lord,--

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: I'll have it so. My steward!

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: Here, my lord.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: So fitly? Go, bid all my friends again, Lucius, Lucullus, and Sempronius: All, sirrah, all: I'll once more feast the rascals.

lines.speaker: flavius
lines.text: O my lord, You only speak from your distracted soul; There is not so much left, to furnish out A moderate table.

lines.speaker: timon
lines.text: Be't not in thy care; go, I charge thee, invite them all: let in the tide Of knaves once more; my cook and I'll provide.
Exeunt
